author: David Isaacson
title: World Tour next stop for Ryder’s cycling stars | Other Sport
text:
Daryl Impey during the South African National Road Race Championships in Nelspriut in February. Picture: GALLO IMAGES/DIRK KOTZE Related articles MTN-Qhubeka to become Team Dimension Data Track cycling faces chop at Games Cycling ‘cleaner than a decade ago’ SA team rider claims cycling stage victory in Spain WITH a new title sponsor, MTN-Qhubeka is dreaming of cracking an invitation to the World Tour, the biggest stage in road cycling.
The African outfit — to be known as Team Dimension Data from next year — is ranked 16th in the world, two places within the top 18 they need for the sport’s governing body, the UCI, to offer them a spot.
That could happen in early November, said team principal Doug Ryder. "If the opportunity arose we’d for sure jump in and take it," he said, adding that he was already looking at ways to ensure they could handle the extra bills that come with racing at that level.
"The costs are more because you need to, at the odd time, run a triple programme, but most of it is around logistics — bikes, cars, staff.
"Dimension Data is significant in its support, but we’re hoping to announce one or two partners in the coming days to support us even further to give us the breadth and depth of funding that we need if we do get asked to go to the World Tour."
Qhubeka, which took a wild card entry into the Tour de France this year and finished fifth overall, earned its high ranking by performing solidly throughout the season.
"We won 19 races this year, top 10 placings as well," Ryder said.
The lifeline from Dimension Data, which is already involved in cycling sponsorships, was about more than the World Tour.
"It’s about the sustainability of this team … if we didn’t find a title sponsor, it would be pretty sad for the momentum of what we’ve built and delivered not to continue."
The Olympic selection criteria for SA are dependent on World Tour rankings, where South Africans do not feature highly.
Daryl Impey is a regular competitor for the Orica-GreenEDGE team, but as a support rider, he does not get the ranking he deserves.
Qhubeka, as a Pro-Continental team, do not earn World Tour points, even when racing in World Tour events such as the Tour de France.
SA are unlikely to send a men’s road team to next year’s Rio Games. But Ryder believes a South African team would be competitive in Brazil.
"We’ve got an incredible bunch of guys. Daryl would be the lead guy because of his experience and time on the World Tour.
"You’d have Reinardt Janse van Rensburg, you’ve got Louis Meintjes (both Qhubeka) … you’ve got guys who have done so well this year in the biggest races in the world against the best riders in the world.
"If you put a full team together, I really believe you’d have a solid opportunity to go top 10 and (then) … the podium’s not that far away."
SA not good enough for the Olympics? But here they are with a sniff of making the World Tour.
